questions.text:
A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of worsening shortness of breath. He has a history of long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril, amlodipine, and metformin. His wife reports that he only takes his medications every second or third day. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He stopped drinking alcohol 3 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 167/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Pulmonary examination is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral metoprolol can be used in the treatment of hypertension, especially in patients with concomitant heart failure. However, metoprolol should be avoided in patients with acute decompensated heart failure, which this patient most likely has, as this drug decreases myocardial contractility, resulting in left ventricular dysfunction and further worsening of pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled albuterol and corticosteroids are typically indicated in patients with respiratory distress due to obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). This type of condition manifests with wheezing and rhonchi, not the bibasilar lung crackles heard in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with respiratory distress (acute dyspnea, hypoxemia) and bibasilar crackles on pulmonary auscultation. In conjunction with his history of long-standing, poorly controlled hypertension, these findings indicate pulmonary edema due to acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF). As this patient is hemodynamically stable, management includes oxygen supplementation, proper positioning (raising the head of the bed), and intravenous loop diuretics such as furosemide. Diuresis results in a decrease in intravascular volume, thereby reducing the cardiac preload, central venous pressure, and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, which, in turn, reduces pulmonary edema. Furthermore, in patients with pulmonary edema, furosemide causes transient venodilation, further reducing pulmonary congestion, even before the onset of diuresis. If respiratory distress persists, treatment with vasodilators for ADHF (e.g., nitroglycerin) may be initiated to further reduce preload.

For the appropriate management of ADHF, think LMNOP: Loop diuretics (furosemide), Modify medications, Nitrates, Oxygen if hypoxic, Position (with elevated upper body).

D) INCORRECT:

Chest tube placement is indicated in patients with pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion. Although this patient presents with symptoms associated with these conditions (dyspnea, hypoxemia), auscultation would typically reveal decreased breath sounds rather than the bibasilar crackles heard in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics may be indicated for patients with respiratory distress due to pneumonia. This condition, however, typically manifests with unilateral crackles, fever, pleuritic chest pain, and productive cough rather than the bibasilar lung crackles that are heard in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Intravenous corticosteroids are administered in patients with respiratory distress due to acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD). Although this patient has a long-standing smoking history, which puts him at increased risk for COPD, auscultation would reveal wheezing or rhonchi, not the bibasilar lung crackles heard here. AECOPD classically manifests with increasing frequency or severity of cough, and/or increasing volume or purulence of sputum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, who gave birth at 39 weeks' gestation via cesarean section under general anesthesia 2 days ago presents with acute chest pain and difficulty breathing. The pregnancy was complicated by hypothyroidism and treated with L-thyroxine. The patient has a history of mild asthma. There is no family history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows cyanosis of the lips. Dull percussion, diminished breathing sounds, and decreased fremitus are heard at the left lung base. An x-ray of the chest shows displacement of fissures and homogeneous opacification of the lower lobe of the left lung. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Fluid accumulation in the alveolar interstitium
Entrance of amniotic fluid into maternal circulation
Chronic inflammation of the respiratory system
Bacterial infection of the alveolar space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Postoperative pulmonary edema with interstitial fluid accumulation is a possible complication after surgery, especially in patients with cardiac disease but also, e.g., after inappropriate volume substitution. As it occurs within the first hour after surgery in most cases and an x-ray would show a bilateral, perihilar haze, peribronchial cuffing, and Kerley B lines, another diagnosis is more likely.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view)

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (hatched green overlay) and the perihilar air space opacities (green overlay) have a bat wing, or butterfly, configuration. Linear interstitial opacities representing Kerley A lines (orange dashed lines) radiate from the hila to the apices and Kerley B lines (white dashed lines) are seen in the lateral mid zones. The costophrenic angles are blunted (arrows) from bilateral pleural effusions.

These features are characteristically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but life-threatening condition in the peripartum period that is characterized by respiratory failure and an anaphylactoid response. AFE typically manifests during or shortly after delivery with hypotension, arrhythmias, dyspnea, tachypnea, cyanosis, and altered consciousness. This patient's blood pressure is normal. Additionally, her physical examination and x-ray findings are more consistent with another diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic inflammation of the respiratory system is associated with asthma and COPD, which increase the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications (e.g., atelectasis, pneumonia) in patients undergoing surgery. Although this patient has a history of mild asthma, this does not explain, e.g., the dull percussion note or x-ray findings. An x-ray would show signs of pulmonary hyperinflation that are diffuse and bilateral, rather than opacification limited to one region of the lung.

D) CORRECT:

Cesarean section and general anesthesia are associated with reduced lung compliance, diminished ventilation, retained airway secretions, and postoperative pain resulting in poor cough and shallow breathing, which then increases the risk of atelectasis. The onset of this patient's symptoms within 72 hours of surgery is highly suggestive of postoperative atelectasis. The x-ray findings are consistent with this diagnosis. Deep breathing exercises, directed coughing, and incentive spirometry should be initiated. Suctioning of secretions and/or continuous positive airway pressure may also be beneficial.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (AP view, supine position)

Mediastinal shift (big arrow) to the left.
Left lung reduced in volume (outline with small arrows). Basal opacities are seen. The left hemidiaphragm is not demarcated.

E) INCORRECT:

General anesthesia and surgery are associated with reduced lung compliance, diminished ventilation, retained airway secretions, and postoperative pain resulting in poor cough and shallow breathing, which then increases the risk of postoperative pneumonia. Postoperative pneumonia typically occurs within 5 days of surgery and manifests with fever, productive cough, and leukocytosis. An x-ray would show pulmonary infiltrates.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (left: PA view; right: lateral view) of a patient with history of pneumonia

Extensive heterogeneous air space consolidation (green overlay) in the left upper lobe abuts part of the major fissure (dashed line). A small pleural effusion is present.

Examples of causes of pulmonary consolidation that can mimic the appearance of infectious pneumonia include organizing pneumonia, malignancy (adenocarcinoma, lymphoma), and pulmonary hemorrhage.

Red: meniscus of pleural effusion

F) INCORRECT:

Acute onset of chest pain and difficulty breathing within 72 hours after surgery, as seen in this patient, should raise suspicion of pulmonary embolism (PE), especially because pregnancy and surgery are important risk factors. However, symptoms of right ventricular strain (e.g., tachycardia, a split second heart sound, and jugular distention) would also be expected. Based on the modified Wells' criteria for PE, this patient has a total score of 1.5 due to recent surgery and immobilization, making PE unlikely (score ≤ 4). Although a chest x-ray may show abnormalities associated with PE (e.g., atelectasis, pleural effusion), these findings are neither sensitive nor specific enough to confirm the diagnosis on their own.
questions.hint: This patient has a common postoperative complication caused by reduced lung compliance and may be asymptomatic or, in more severe cases, present with respiratory distress within 72 hours of surgery.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and chest tightness for 3 hours. She has had an intermittent nonproductive cough for the past two months. Her 16-year old son had an upper respiratory infection last week and was treated with azithromycin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years but stopped smoking 5 years ago. She works at a cattle ranch. She appears anxious and is unable to speak in full sentences. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5 F), pulse is 100/min, her blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and respirations are 28/min. A chest x-ray is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



Chest excursion
Breath sounds
Chest percussion
Tactile fremitus



A
asymmetric
decreased
dull
decreased


B
asymmetric
absent
hyperresonant
decreased


C
symmetric
basal crackles
dull
increased


D
asymmetric
basal crackles
dull
increased


E
symmetric
decreased
hyperresonant
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with pleural effusion. When fluid infiltrates the pleural space it insulates sounds originating from the lung parenchyma, which results in a decrease in both breath sounds and tactile fremitus. Cough and dyspnea may be seen in pleural effusion, but there is no evidence of an effusion on this patient's chest x-ray.

B) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with pneumothorax. In this condition, the air in the pleural space leads to hyperresonant percussion and decreased tactile fremitus on the affected side. Pneumothorax should always be considered in patients with new-onset shortness of breath. However, there is no evidence of pneumothorax on this patient's chest x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with pulmonary fibrosis. Patients with pulmonary fibrosis often have basal crackles on auscultation and can present with normal or increased tactile fremitus. Pulmonary fibrosis can manifest with dyspnea and a nonproductive cough, and it may be caused by farmer's lung, which this patient's occupation is a risk factor for. However, pulmonary fibrosis typically has a more chronic and progressive course than what is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

These clinical exam findings are consistent with a consolidative process, such as lobar pneumonia. While pneumonia can also present with dyspnea, this patient lacks other symptoms of pneumonia, such as productive cough, fever, malaise, and/or chills. Furthermore, her chest x-ray does not have evidence of consolidation.

E) CORRECT:

Decreased breath sounds, hyperresonant percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus are consistent with pulmonary hyperinflation, which in this case is secondary to the patient's severe asthma exacerbation. Wheezing is another typical finding in asthma exacerbation but can be absent in very severe cases.

Based on her history, this patient likely has nonallergic asthma, which often manifests later in life and is associated with smoking exposure.
questions.hint: Chest x-ray shows parenchymal lucency, a low, flattened diaphragm, and wide intercostal spaces, all of which are signs of pulmonary hyperinflation. These findings, combined with the patient's history and clinical findings, are concerning for a severe asthma exacerbation.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the veterans’ administration outpatient clinic because of worsening dyspnea, dry cough, and left-sided chest pain for the past 3 weeks. He has been feeling more fatigued than usual over the past 2 months. He has hypertension, chronic tinnitus, and osteoarthritis of both hips. He takes enalapril and ketorolac as needed. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 38 years. Temperature is 37.6°C (98.9°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 141/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Pulmonary examination is shown. There is dullness to percussion over the left lung base. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's pulmonary findings?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with pneumothorax may present with dyspnea, chest pain, and unilaterally decreased breath sounds on auscultation, all of which are seen here. However, pneumothorax typically has a more acute presentation and the chest wall would be hyperresonant rather than dull on percussion.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with pulmonary edema may present with dyspnea, cough, and dullness on percussion. However, bilateral fine or coarse crackles (depending on the severity of the edema) rather than unilateral decreased breath sounds would be heard on lung auscultation.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the left lung base suggest pleural effusion, which is characterized by the presence of liquid between the lung and thoracic cavity. The liquid increases the density of the thoracic cavity where the pleural effusion is located, resulting in dullness to percussion, and decreases the transmission of breath sounds, resulting in decreased breath sounds on auscultation.

In this 62-year-old patient with a 38 pack-year smoking history as well as a history of increased fatigue, dyspnea, chest pain, and dry cough, a malignant pleural effusion due to a pulmonary malignancy should be suspected. He should undergo further evaluation with a CT scan of the chest and possibly thoracocentesis to assess for pulmonary malignancy.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

There is marked opacification (green overlay) of the middle and lower left hemithorax from pleural effusion and passive atelectasis of the adjacent lung. No gastric air bubble is seen projecting over the lower left hemithorax to suggest marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm from a large amount of atelectasis, but concave upper lateral borders, or menisci (white dashed lines), help confirm the presence of effusion extending to the mid thorax.

The margins of the cardiac silhouette and left hemidiaphragm are obscured. Additionally, the cardiac silhouette is shifted slightly to the right (indicated by blue line and arrow) and the left bronchial tree is slightly elevated (indicated by black lines and arrow).

In the right hemithorax, a small meniscus from effusion is seen laterally (indicated by red line). Additionally, increased opacification projects through the right hemidiaphragm indicating effusion in the posterior sulcus (red overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic bronchitis can present with worsening dyspnea and cough, both of which are seen here. In addition, this patient's smoking history increases the risk of developing this condition. However, pulmonary examination in chronic bronchitis typically shows hyperresonance on percussion as well as bilateral wheezing and rhonchi rather than unilateral decreased breath sounds on auscultation. Moreover, chronic bronchitis manifests with a productive rather than dry cough.

E) INCORRECT:

Foreign body aspiration can lead to atelectasis (due to airway obstruction) and may, therefore, manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, unilaterally decreased breath sounds on auscultation, and dullness to percussion, all of which are seen here. However, atelectasis typically manifests more acutely. Moreover, foreign body aspiration is rare in adults with intact cough and swallowing mechanisms.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with pneumonia may present with chest pain, dyspnea, and dullness to percussion. However, coarse crackles are also typically heard on lung auscultation. In addition, this patient does not have other characteristic features of pneumonia, such as fever and productive cough with purulent sputum.
questions.hint: Pulmonary examination shows unilateral decreased breath sounds over the left lung base.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of shortness of breath, chest pain, and a cough for 2 days. The pain is exacerbated by deep inspiration. He has a history of congestive heart failure, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include metoprolol, lisinopril, spironolactone, metformin, and simvastatin. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Examination shows dullness to percussion and an increased tactile fremitus in the right lower lung field. Auscultation over this area shows bronchial breath sounds and whispered pectoriloquy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In pulmonary parenchymal consolidation, fluid accumulates in previously air-filled lung tissue, increasing the transmission of low-frequency sound waves (i.e., increased tactile fremitus, whispered pectoriloquy, egophony) while dulling the sound upon percussion. A common cause of pulmonary consolidation is pneumonia, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given the acute onset of dyspnea, chest pain, cough, and fever. Other causes include pulmonary edema, aspiration of fluids, pulmonary hemorrhage, and lung cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Pleural fluid accumulation causes pleural effusion, which can manifest with dyspnea, cough, pleuritic chest pain, and dullness to percussion over the fluid collection. However, pleural effusion is not associated with increased fremitus or whispered pectoriloquy. Dullness to percussion results from fluid collection outside the lung parenchyma, decreasing sound transmission from the lungs. Conversely, fluid collection within the lung parenchyma increases sound transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

Transudation of fluid into the alveoli and the pulmonary interstitium causes pulmonary edema due to left ventricular failure. The backup of fluid seen in left ventricular failure leads to increased hydrostatic pressure in pulmonary capillaries and, consequently, cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Severe pulmonary edema can also manifest with dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and whispered pectoriloquy, all of which are seen here. These signs, however, would manifest bilaterally rather than focally and unilaterally. Furthermore, findings of pulmonary edema would typically include bilateral basilar crackles or rales on respiratory examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Air trapping occurs in diseases that retain an abnormal amount of air in the lungs, particularly during expiration (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma), resulting in pulmonary hyperinflation. The trapped air causes a diffuse hyperresonant sound during percussion, along with decreased tactile fremitus and absent whispered pectoriloquy, none of which are seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Ruptured pulmonary blebs can cause spontaneous pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain, both of which are seen here. However, examination would also likely show decreased or absent breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, decreased or absent fremitus, and absent whispered pectoriloquy, none of which are seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

The most common cause of pulmonary infarction is pulmonary embolism (PE), which can manifest with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, and decreased oxygen saturation. However, PE does not explain the dullness to percussion, increased fremitus, bronchial breath sounds, or whispered pectoriloquy observed on examination. Furthermore, this patient lacks any risk factors for PE, such as immobilization, recent surgery, active cancer, trauma, or hormonal therapy.
questions.hint: Dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, bronchial breath sounds, and whispered pectoriloquy are alterations in sound conduction caused by a loss of aeration in lung tissue.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for worsening fatigue and dyspnea for several months. She has not been seen by a physician in 10 years. She is also concerned about the appearance of her fingernails. A photograph of her hands is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for the patient's nail findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nail changes in chronic psoriatic arthritis include nail pitting, onycholysis, nail-bed hyperkeratosis, and splinter hemorrhages. The condition is not associated with digital clubbing. Moreover, psoriatic arthritis would not explain this patient's fatigue and dyspnea.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic iron deficiency anemia can cause concave spooning of the nail (koilonychia), but it is not associated with digital clubbing. The exact mechanism of koilonychia is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by disordered keratinization of the nail matrix secondary to iron deficiency. Although anemia could explain this patient's worsening fatigue, dyspnea usually occurs only on exertion. Moreover, additional signs, such as pallor, would be expected.
Image Description:

Fingers (A) and thumb (B) of the right hand of a 22-year-old female patient presenting with weakness, weight loss, and reduced appetite

The nails are centrally concave and bend upwards distally, resulting in a characteristic spoon shape.

The most common cause of koilonychia is iron deficiency anemia, as was the case here.

C) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common respiratory cause of digital clubbing in developed countries. The exact pathophysiology of clubbing is unknown but is thought to be the result of chronic hypoxia, which is seen in IPF due to a progressive destruction of pulmonary parenchyma. Hypoxia induces the release of vascular endothelial growth factor, which stimulates angiogenesis in the nail beds and increases blood flow. Additionally, platelet-derived growth factor released from megakaryocytes induces connective tissue proliferation. This fibrovascular proliferation appears as digital clubbing.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma causes episodic hypoxia due to acute lower airway obstructions. However, digital clubbing is a result of chronic hypoxia. Moreover, she lacks characteristic symptoms of bronchial asthma such as a persistent, dry cough with end-expiratory wheezes.

E) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with consequent pulmonary hypertension results in shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) and delivery of deoxygenated blood to the lower extremities. Chronic hypoxia in the lower extremities (seen initially as differential cyanosis) results in digital clubbing that selectively affects toenails (differential clubbing). Although pulmonary hypertension secondary to PDA can develop in this patient's age group and manifest with dyspnea, it would not cause digital clubbing of the fingernails.

F) INCORRECT:

Although advanced COPD is a cause of chronic hypoxia, it does not cause digital clubbing. The reasons for this are unknown. The presence of digital clubbing in a patient with COPD is concerning for an underlying lung carcinoma. Although COPD can cause dyspnea, this patient does not present with its pathognomic features (e.g., ≥ 3 months of chronic productive cough in 2 consecutive years).
questions.hint: This patient's fingers show digital clubbing, which is most commonly associated with prolonged hypoxia.

questions.text: A previously healthy 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever, cough, and right-sided chest pain. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F) and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination shows dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and egophony in the right lower lung field. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The collapse of a lung segment (e.g., due to pneumonia or atelectasis) can also cause localized dullness to percussion, as seen here. However, lung collapse is typically characterized by decreased tactile fremitus, unlike what is seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluid in the pleural space (e.g., due to empyema, pleural effusion) can also cause dullness to percussion, but tactile fremitus would be decreased over the affected area, unlike what is seen in this patient. Dullness to percussion results from the fact that fluid collection outside of the lung parenchyma decreases sound transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluid in the interstitial space (e.g., due to pulmonary edema) typically manifests with crackles on pulmonary examination. In the early stages of pulmonary edema, crackles may only be present during late inspiration. Severe pulmonary edema can also manifest with dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and egophony, but these signs would be expected bilaterally rather than focally and unilaterally, as seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Dullness to percussion can indicate pleural effusion, atelectasis, or lung consolidation, but the findings of increased tactile fremitus and egophony make a consolidation most likely. Increased tactile fremitus and egophony occur because a consolidation conducts sound better than air. While pneumonia is the most common cause of a localized consolidation, consolidation can also be due to any infiltrative process (e.g., tumor, pulmonary edema).

E) INCORRECT:

Findings expected with air in the pleural space (e.g., due to pneumothorax, tension pneumothorax) include hyper-resonance to percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, decreased breath sounds, and absent egophony. This patient's examination findings are not consistent with pneumothorax.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and localized examination findings suggest community-acquired pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man comes to the office because of a productive cough, limited exercise tolerance, and fatigue. He reports that he is always short of breath after climbing up the flights of stairs to his apartment. He has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and a 20-year history of hypertension. Current medications include insulin, amlodipine, ramipril, and a fish oil supplement. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Temperature is 37.6°C (98.9°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 133/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Pulmonary examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient's symptoms?
Video

choices.text: Accumulation of fluid in the pleural space
Accumulation of fluid in the alveoli
Entry of air into pleural space
Bacterial infection of the pulmonary parenchyma

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Collapse of the alveoli causes atelectasis, which can manifest with dyspnea. However, lung auscultation in atelectasis typically discloses decreased or absent breath sounds over the affected lobe(s), rather than the bibasilar wheezing heard in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of fluid in the pleural space leads to pleural effusion, which can manifest with dyspnea and cough. However, the cough in pleural effusion is typically nonproductive, and lung auscultation usually discloses decreased breath sounds in the affected side, unlike the bilateral wheezing heard here.

C) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of fluid in the alveoli leads to pulmonary edema, which can manifest with cough and dyspnea. However, lung auscultation in pulmonary edema typically discloses bilateral fine or coarse crackles (depending on the severity of the edema), rather than wheezing.

D) INCORRECT:

Entry of air into the pleural space leads to pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea, as seen here. Furthermore, this patient's smoking history increases his risk of developing this condition. However, lung auscultation in pneumothorax typically shows unilaterally decreased or absent breath sounds, rather than the bilateral wheezing heard in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

The bibasilar end-expiratory wheezing on lung auscultation in this patient suggests a turbulent passage of air through narrowed (obstructed) lower airways, which occurs both in asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to bronchial inflammation. These findings, in combination with this patient's productive cough, dyspnea on exertion, and history of heavy smoking, suggest COPD. Additional pulmonary examination findings characteristic of COPD include hyperresonant percussion, decreased breath sounds (“silent lung”), and rhonchi. This patient should undergo further evaluation with pulmonary function tests to confirm the diagnosis.

In a patient with COPD, pulmonary function tests show irreversible airflow limitation (postbronchodilator FEV1/FVC < 0.70).

F) INCORRECT:

Bacterial infection of the pulmonary parenchyma causes pneumonia, which can manifest with dyspnea and productive cough, both of which are found here. However, pneumonia is typically unilateral, and thus associated with unilateral coarse crackles on lung auscultation. Moreover, pneumonia is associated with fever, and this patient has a normal temperature.
questions.hint: Lung auscultation in this patient shows bilateral end-expiratory wheezing.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of headache, nasal discharge, and dry cough. He has had no dyspnea, visual changes, or painful eye movements. He has not been going to work during this time because he has been sleeping poorly. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 8 years. The patient is allergic to penicillin. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hg. Examination shows clear mucus in the nostrils and the posterior oropharynx. Pulmonary examination is shown. There are no focal neurologic findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhaled beclomethasone therapy is indicated for the maintenance treatment of asthma, which typically presents with a dry cough that affects sleep quality and is often associated with rhinorrhea. However, in asthma, rhinorrhea is usually due to chronic allergic rhinitis, and characteristic features of lower airway involvement (e.g., dyspnea and chest tightness, end-expiratory wheezes) would be expected. While inhaled beclomethasone has no benefit in patients with acute viral and bacterial rhinosinusitis, short-term application of topical, intranasal steroids (e.g., fluticasone, beclomethasone) may be indicated to reduce nasal symptoms and inflammation.

B) CORRECT:

The standard of care in acute viral rhinosinusitis is reassurance and close follow-up. Uncomplicated viral sinusitis is generally self-limiting, and supportive therapy with rest, hydration, antipyretics, and oral analgesics is sufficient. In addition, topical, intranasal steroids (e.g., fluticasone, beclomethasone), nasal saline lavage, and decongestive nose drops (e.g., oxymetazoline) can provide symptomatic relief. If bacterial rhinosinusitis or bacterial superinfection is suspected, antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanate or, in this adult patient with penicillin allergy, with doxycycline, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin, is indicated for 5–10 days. Further imaging tests are generally not recommended unless a complication (e.g., orbital cellulitis) or a differential diagnosis (e.g., nasal polyps) is suspected.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the sinuses is the imaging modality of choice in acute sinusitis. However, a CT scan is indicated only if symptoms fail to improve within 7 days of diagnosis or worsen during the initial management of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis, in the case of suspected complications (e.g., osteomyelitis, orbital cellulitis), or to rule out differential diagnoses (e.g., neoplasms). This patient has only had symptoms of acute viral rhinosinusitis for 4 days and does not have visual changes or painful eye movements that might suggest a complication. Performing a CT scan would only expose the patient to unnecessary radiation.
Image Description:

CT paranasal sinuses (coronal plane) of a patient with acute sinusitis

The right maxillary sinus (green overlay) is completely opacified. Extensive soft tissue density material (red overlay) is also present in the ipsilateral nasal cavity and the right ethmoid sinus is nearly completely opacified.

D) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is considered a second-line antibiotic for the treatment of acute bacterial sinusitis and may also be used in patients with penicillin allergy, like this patient. However, this patient has no characteristic features of a bacterial infection (i.e., severe symptoms initial ≥ 3 days, > 39°C fever, facial pain, purulent nasal discharge) or superinfection (i.e., persistent symptoms for ≥ 10 days without clinical improvement, initially improving and then worsening symptoms after 5–6 days). Therefore, antibiotics are not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Sputum gram stain and culture are indicated for the diagnostic workup of community-acquired pneumonia if symptoms are severe or persistent, or if the patient is hospitalized. This patient does not have features suggestive of typical pneumonia. While atypical pneumonia often manifests with headaches and dry cough, other constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, myalgias) and dyspnea are usually present. Microbiological tests are not indicated for acute viral rhinosinusitis unless complications (e.g., orbital cellulitis, osteomyelitis) are suspected based on clinical presentation (e.g., visual changes, eye movements).

F) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin, with or without clavulanate, is considered the first-line treatment for acute bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, this patient has no characteristic features of a bacterial infection, (i.e., severe symptoms initial ≥ 3 days; > 39°C fever, facial pain, purulent nasal discharge) or superinfection (i.e., persistent symptoms for ≥ 10 days without clinical improvement, initially improving and then worsening symptoms after 5–6 days). Moreover, this patient has a history of penicillin allergy; amoxicillin-clavulanate should, therefore, be avoided.

G) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray is commonly used to diagnose community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), which typically manifests with fever and cough. However, this patient has no other features suggestive of CAP (e.g., high fever, severe malaise, tachypnea, dyspnea, purulent sputum). Moreover, his pulmonary examination is normal; no crackles or rales are present. A chest x-ray is not required for the diagnosis of acute rhinosinusitis and would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation.
questions.hint: This patient's rhinorrhea, fever, headache, dry cough, duration of symptoms, and physical examination findings are consistent with acute viral rhinosinusitis.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of respiratory distress. Her aunt and uncle, with whom she is spending the weekend, report that she had some coughing and congestion during the past day but was generally well until she woke up crying and “couldn’t catch her breath.” The aunt thinks the child’s voice sounds different from its usual tone. She is unsure of the child’s vaccination status but believes she was previously healthy. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
The child’s current temperature is 38.5°C, her respiratory rate is 38 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 98% while she breathes ambient air.
As you enter the room, you can hear inspiratory stridor and a barking cough. The child is lying in bed in moderate respiratory distress but appears nontoxic. She has nasal congestion and moderate subcostal and intercostal retractions. Chest examination reveals symmetric air entry bilaterally. There are no wheezes or rales. She appears well hydrated, and the remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this child?

choices.text: Arrange for an airway evaluation in the operating room
Obtain anteroposterior and lateral neck radiographs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral decubitus radiographs could show unilateral hyperinflation in the case of an aspirated foreign body in the lower airway. There is no history of choking in this patient, and the lack of wheeze or asymmetric air entry on auscultation makes foreign-body aspiration unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Evaluation of the airway in the operating room would be appropriate for a toxic-appearing child with features of epiglottitis. Epiglottitis manifests with the classic three Ds: drooling, dysphagia, and distress. Patients are usually sitting up in bed in a tripod position and appear toxic. A lateral neck radiograph would show the classic thumb sign, but all testing should be deferred until the airway is secure.

C) INCORRECT:

A systemic glucocorticoid, such as dexamethasone, would be appropriate to provide along with racemic epinephrine in patients with moderate-to-severe symptoms consistent with classic croup. However, in this case, the patient should undergo further evaluation before being given systemic glucocorticoids, which, for example, might be contraindicated if a mediastinal mass were to be discovered.

D) CORRECT:

Stridor in a child 6 months to 5 years of age with nasal congestion and respiratory distress would be most consistent with a diagnosis of croup (laryngotracheitis), and empiric treatment would be indicated. However, croup is less common in children older than 3 years of age, and in those >5 years of age, classic croup due to viral respiratory pathogens is unusual. Older children presenting with stridor should therefore be evaluated for other causes of the stridor, starting with neck radiographs, which would identify a foreign body or other neck process. Although neck radiographs are not indicated in classic croup, they are helpful when the diagnosis is in question, the course is atypical, or the patient does not respond to treatment.

Key learning point: The best next step to evaluate stridor in a patient outside the normal age range for croup is to obtain anteroposterior and lateral neck radiographs.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of stridor and the lack of wheeze make asthma unlikely in this case. Therefore, albuterol is unnecessary.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the veterans’ administration outpatient clinic because of worsening dyspnea, dry cough, and left-sided chest pain for the past 3 weeks. He has been feeling more fatigued than usual over the past 2 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 38 years. Temperature is 37.6°C (98.9°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 141/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Pulmonary examination is shown. There is dullness to percussion over the left lung base. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's pulmonary findings?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with pneumothorax may present with dyspnea, chest pain, and unilaterally decreased breath sounds on auscultation, all of which are seen here. However, pneumothorax typically has a more acute presentation and the chest wall would be hyperresonant rather than dull on percussion.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with pulmonary edema may present with dyspnea, cough, and dullness on percussion. However, bilateral fine or coarse crackles (depending on the severity of the edema) rather than unilateral decreased breath sounds would be heard on lung auscultation.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the left lung base suggest pleural effusion, which is characterized by the presence of liquid between the lung and thoracic cavity. The liquid increases the density of the thoracic cavity where the pleural effusion is located, resulting in dullness to percussion, and decreases the transmission of breath sounds, resulting in decreased breath sounds on auscultation.

In this 62-year-old patient with a 38 pack-year smoking history as well as a history of increased fatigue, dyspnea, chest pain, and dry cough, a malignant pleural effusion due to a pulmonary malignancy should be suspected. He should undergo further evaluation with a CT scan of the chest and possibly thoracocentesis to assess for pulmonary malignancy.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

There is marked opacification (green overlay) of the middle and lower left hemithorax from pleural effusion and passive atelectasis of the adjacent lung. No gastric air bubble is seen projecting over the lower left hemithorax to suggest marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm from a large amount of atelectasis, but concave upper lateral borders, or menisci (white dashed lines), help confirm the presence of effusion extending to the mid thorax.

The margins of the cardiac silhouette and left hemidiaphragm are obscured. Additionally, the cardiac silhouette is shifted slightly to the right (indicated by blue line and arrow) and the left bronchial tree is slightly elevated (indicated by black lines and arrow).

In the right hemithorax, a small meniscus from effusion is seen laterally (indicated by red line). Additionally, increased opacification projects through the right hemidiaphragm indicating effusion in the posterior sulcus (red overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic bronchitis can present with worsening dyspnea and cough, both of which are seen here. In addition, this patient's smoking history increases the risk of developing this condition. However, pulmonary examination in chronic bronchitis typically shows hyperresonance on percussion as well as bilateral wheezing and rhonchi rather than unilateral decreased breath sounds on auscultation. Moreover, chronic bronchitis manifests with a productive rather than dry cough.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with pneumonia may present with chest pain, dyspnea, and dullness to percussion. However, coarse crackles are also typically heard on lung auscultation. In addition, this patient does not have other characteristic features of pneumonia, such as fever and productive cough with purulent sputum.
questions.hint: Pulmonary examination shows unilateral decreased breath sounds over the left lung base.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the office for worsening fatigue and dyspnea for several months. She has not been seen by a healthcare professional in 10 years. She is also concerned about the appearance of her fingernails. A photograph of her hands is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for the patient's nail findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nail changes in chronic psoriatic arthritis include nail pitting, onycholysis, nail-bed hyperkeratosis, and splinter hemorrhages. The condition is not associated with digital clubbing. Moreover, psoriatic arthritis would not explain this patient's fatigue and dyspnea.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic iron deficiency anemia can cause concave spooning of the nail (koilonychia), but it is not associated with digital clubbing. The exact mechanism of koilonychia is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by disordered keratinization of the nail matrix secondary to iron deficiency. Although anemia could explain this patient's worsening fatigue, dyspnea usually occurs only on exertion. Moreover, additional signs, such as pallor, would be expected.
Image Description:

Fingers (A) and thumb (B) of the right hand of a 22-year-old female patient presenting with weakness, weight loss, and reduced appetite

The nails are centrally concave and bend upwards distally, resulting in a characteristic spoon shape.

The most common cause of koilonychia is iron deficiency anemia, as was the case here.

C) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common respiratory cause of digital clubbing in developed countries. The exact pathophysiology of clubbing is unknown but is thought to be the result of chronic hypoxia, which is seen in IPF due to a progressive destruction of pulmonary parenchyma. Hypoxia induces the release of vascular endothelial growth factor, which stimulates angiogenesis in the nail beds and increases blood flow. Additionally, platelet-derived growth factor released from megakaryocytes induces connective tissue proliferation. This fibrovascular proliferation appears as digital clubbing.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma causes episodic hypoxia due to acute lower airway obstructions. However, digital clubbing is a result of chronic hypoxia. Moreover, she lacks characteristic symptoms of bronchial asthma such as a persistent, dry cough with end-expiratory wheezes.

E) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with consequent pulmonary hypertension results in shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) and delivery of deoxygenated blood to the lower extremities. Chronic hypoxia in the lower extremities (seen initially as differential cyanosis) results in digital clubbing that selectively affects toenails (differential clubbing). Although pulmonary hypertension secondary to PDA can develop in this patient's age group and manifest with dyspnea, it would not cause digital clubbing of the fingernails.
questions.hint: This patient's fingers show digital clubbing, which is most commonly associated with prolonged hypoxia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of shortness of breath, chest pain, and a cough for 2 days. The pain is exacerbated by deep inspiration. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Examination shows dullness to percussion and an increased tactile fremitus in the right lower lung field. Auscultation over this area shows bronchial breath sounds and whispered pectoriloquy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In pulmonary parenchymal consolidation, fluid accumulates in previously air-filled lung tissue, increasing the transmission of low-frequency sound waves (i.e., increased tactile fremitus, whispered pectoriloquy, egophony) while dulling the sound upon percussion. A common cause of pulmonary consolidation is pneumonia, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given the acute onset of dyspnea, chest pain, cough, and fever. Other causes include pulmonary edema, aspiration of fluids, pulmonary hemorrhage, and lung cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Pleural fluid accumulation causes pleural effusion, which can manifest with dyspnea, cough, pleuritic chest pain, and dullness to percussion over the fluid collection. However, pleural effusion is not associated with increased fremitus or whispered pectoriloquy. Dullness to percussion results from fluid collection outside the lung parenchyma, decreasing sound transmission from the lungs. Conversely, fluid collection within the lung parenchyma increases sound transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

Transudation of fluid into the alveoli and the pulmonary interstitium causes pulmonary edema due to left ventricular failure. The backup of fluid seen in left ventricular failure leads to increased hydrostatic pressure in pulmonary capillaries and, consequently, cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Severe pulmonary edema can also manifest with dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and whispered pectoriloquy, all of which are seen here. These signs, however, would manifest bilaterally rather than focally and unilaterally. Furthermore, findings of pulmonary edema would typically include bilateral basilar crackles or rales on respiratory examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Air trapping occurs in diseases that retain an abnormal amount of air in the lungs, particularly during expiration (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma), resulting in pulmonary hyperinflation. The trapped air causes a diffuse hyperresonant sound during percussion, along with decreased tactile fremitus and absent whispered pectoriloquy, none of which are seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Ruptured pulmonary blebs can cause spontaneous pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain, both of which are seen here. However, examination would also likely show decreased or absent breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, decreased or absent fremitus, and absent whispered pectoriloquy, none of which are seen here.
questions.hint: Dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, bronchial breath sounds, and whispered pectoriloquy are alterations in sound conduction caused by a loss of aeration in lung tissue.

questions.text: A previously healthy 66-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-day history of fever, cough, and right-sided chest pain. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F) and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination shows dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and egophony in the right lower lung field. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The collapse of a lung segment (e.g., due to pneumonia or atelectasis) can also cause localized dullness to percussion, as seen here. However, lung collapse is typically characterized by decreased tactile fremitus, unlike what is seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluid in the pleural space (e.g., due to empyema, pleural effusion) can also cause dullness to percussion, but tactile fremitus would be decreased over the affected area, unlike what is seen in this patient. Dullness to percussion results from the fact that fluid collection outside of the lung parenchyma decreases sound transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluid in the interstitial space (e.g., due to pulmonary edema) typically manifests with crackles on pulmonary examination. In the early stages of pulmonary edema, crackles may only be present during late inspiration. Severe pulmonary edema can also manifest with dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and egophony, but these signs would be expected bilaterally rather than focally and unilaterally, as seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Dullness to percussion can indicate pleural effusion, atelectasis, or lung consolidation, but the findings of increased tactile fremitus and egophony make a consolidation most likely. Increased tactile fremitus and egophony occur because a consolidation conducts sound better than air. While pneumonia is the most common cause of a localized consolidation, consolidation can also be due to any infiltrative process (e.g., tumor, pulmonary edema).

E) INCORRECT:

Findings expected with air in the pleural space (e.g., due to pneumothorax, tension pneumothorax) include hyper-resonance to percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, decreased breath sounds, and absent egophony. This patient's examination findings are not consistent with pneumothorax.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and localized examination findings suggest community-acquired pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath over two weeks and a mild cough. He has no fever. Examination shows absent breath sounds on the left side, dullness to percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus. The trachea is deviated to the right (see report).
Chest radiograph: Opacification on the left side
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax typically presents with hyperresonant percussion due to air accumulation, not dullness. It usually has an acute presentation, unlike the progressive symptoms over two weeks described here. The chest radiograph would show hyperlucency, not opacification.

B) INCORRECT:

Left lung collapse, or atelectasis, would cause tracheal deviation toward the affected side due to volume loss. In this scenario, the trachea deviates to the right, suggesting a process with increased volume, such as a pleural effusion. Decreased tactile fremitus and opacification align more with fluid accumulation.

C) INCORRECT:

Lobar pneumonia typically presents with bronchial breath sounds and increased tactile fremitus due to alveolar consolidation. The absence of fever and the presence of tracheal deviation to the right, along with decreased tactile fremitus, are inconsistent with lobar pneumonia.

D) CORRECT:

A large left-sided pleural effusion manifests with decreased or absent breath sounds, dullness to percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus due to fluid accumulation in the pleural space. The fluid acts as a barrier to sound and vibration transmission. Significant fluid volume can cause tracheal deviation to the opposite side, in this case, to the right. The chest radiograph showing left-sided opacification supports the presence of fluid, correlating with the physical examination findings and indicating lung compression by the effusion.

Key learning point: Tracheal deviation and dullness to percussion on one side of the chest suggest a large pleural effusion, which can cause the trachea to shift away from the affected side.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of worsening dyspnea, dry cough, and left-sided chest pain. He reports increased fatigue over the past 2 months. He has a 38-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His temperature is 37.6°C, pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 141/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Pulmonary examination reveals dullness to percussion over the left lung base. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for his pulmonary findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with pneumonia may present with chest pain, dyspnea, and dullness to percussion. However, coarse crackles are also typically heard on lung auscultation. In addition, this patient does not have other characteristic features of pneumonia, such as fever and productive cough with purulent sputum.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic bronchitis can present with worsening dyspnea and cough, both of which are seen here. In addition, this patient's smoking history increases the risk of developing this condition. However, pulmonary examination in chronic bronchitis typically shows hyperresonance on percussion as well as bilateral wheezing and rhonchi rather than unilateral decreased breath sounds on auscultation. Moreover, chronic bronchitis manifests with a productive rather than dry cough.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with pulmonary edema may present with dyspnea, cough, and dullness on percussion. However, bilateral fine or coarse crackles (depending on the severity of the edema) rather than unilateral decreased breath sounds would be heard on lung auscultation.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with pneumothorax may present with dyspnea, chest pain, and unilaterally decreased breath sounds on auscultation, all of which are seen here. However, pneumothorax typically has a more acute presentation and the chest wall would be hyperresonant rather than dull on percussion.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the left lung base suggest pleural effusion, which is characterized by the presence of liquid between the lung and thoracic cavity. The liquid increases the density of the thoracic cavity where the pleural effusion is located, resulting in dullness to percussion, and decreases the transmission of breath sounds, resulting in decreased breath sounds on auscultation.

In this 62-year-old patient with a 38 pack-year smoking history as well as a history of increased fatigue, dyspnea, chest pain, and dry cough, a malignant pleural effusion due to a pulmonary malignancy should be suspected. He should undergo further evaluation with a CT scan of the chest and possibly thoracocentesis to assess for pulmonary malignancy.

Key learning point: Pleural effusion presents with dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds due to fluid accumulation between the lung and chest wall.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

There is marked opacification (green overlay) of the middle and lower left hemithorax from pleural effusion and passive atelectasis of the adjacent lung. No gastric air bubble is seen projecting over the lower left hemithorax to suggest marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm from a large amount of atelectasis, but concave upper lateral borders, or menisci (white dashed lines), help confirm the presence of effusion extending to the mid thorax.

The margins of the cardiac silhouette and left hemidiaphragm are obscured. Additionally, the cardiac silhouette is shifted slightly to the right (indicated by blue line and arrow) and the left bronchial tree is slightly elevated (indicated by black lines and arrow).

In the right hemithorax, a small meniscus from effusion is seen laterally (indicated by red line). Additionally, increased opacification projects through the right hemidiaphragm indicating effusion in the posterior sulcus (red overlay).
questions.hint: Pulmonary examination shows unilateral decreased breath sounds over the left lung base.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to your clinic with several months of worsening fatigue and dyspnea. She has not seen a healthcare professional in 10 years. She is also concerned about changes in the appearance of her fingernails. A photograph of her hands is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her nail findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with consequent pulmonary hypertension results in shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) and delivery of deoxygenated blood to the lower extremities. Chronic hypoxia in the lower extremities (seen initially as differential cyanosis) results in digital clubbing that selectively affects toenails (differential clubbing). Although pulmonary hypertension secondary to PDA can develop in this patient's age group and manifest with dyspnea, it would not cause digital clubbing of the fingernails.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma causes episodic hypoxia due to acute lower airway obstructions. However, digital clubbing is a result of chronic hypoxia. Moreover, she lacks characteristic symptoms of bronchial asthma such as a persistent, dry cough with end-expiratory wheezes.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic iron deficiency anemia can cause concave spooning of the nail (koilonychia), but it is not associated with digital clubbing. The exact mechanism of koilonychia is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by disordered keratinization of the nail matrix secondary to iron deficiency. Although anemia could explain this patient's worsening fatigue, dyspnea usually occurs only on exertion. Moreover, additional signs, such as pallor, would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Nail changes in chronic psoriatic arthritis include nail pitting, onycholysis, nail-bed hyperkeratosis, and splinter hemorrhages. The condition is not associated with digital clubbing. Moreover, psoriatic arthritis would not explain this patient's fatigue and dyspnea.

E) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common respiratory cause of digital clubbing in developed countries. The exact pathophysiology of clubbing is unknown but is thought to be the result of chronic hypoxia, which is seen in IPF due to a progressive destruction of pulmonary parenchyma. Hypoxia induces the release of vascular endothelial growth factor, which stimulates angiogenesis in the nail beds and increases blood flow. Additionally, platelet-derived growth factor released from megakaryocytes induces connective tissue proliferation. This fibrovascular proliferation appears as digital clubbing.

Key learning point: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a common cause of digital clubbing due to chronic hypoxia-induced fibrovascular proliferation in the nail beds.
questions.hint: This patient's fingers show digital clubbing, which is most commonly associated with prolonged hypoxia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of shortness of breath, chest pain, and cough. The chest pain worsens with deep inspiration. His temperature is 38.5°C, pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/84 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation on room air is 93%. On examination, there is dullness to percussion and increased tactile fremitus in the right lower lung field. Auscultation reveals bronchial breath sounds and whispered pectoriloquy over the same area. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Air trapping occurs in diseases that retain an abnormal amount of air in the lungs, particularly during expiration (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma), resulting in pulmonary hyperinflation. The trapped air causes a diffuse hyperresonant sound during percussion, along with decreased tactile fremitus and absent whispered pectoriloquy, none of which are seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Pleural fluid accumulation causes pleural effusion, which can manifest with dyspnea, cough, pleuritic chest pain, and dullness to percussion over the fluid collection. However, pleural effusion is not associated with increased fremitus or whispered pectoriloquy. Dullness to percussion results from fluid collection outside the lung parenchyma, decreasing sound transmission from the lungs. Conversely, fluid collection within the lung parenchyma increases sound transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

Ruptured pulmonary blebs can cause spontaneous pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain, both of which are seen here. However, examination would also likely show decreased or absent breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, decreased or absent fremitus, and absent whispered pectoriloquy, none of which are seen here.

D) CORRECT:

In pulmonary parenchymal consolidation, fluid accumulates in previously air-filled lung tissue, increasing the transmission of low-frequency sound waves (i.e., increased tactile fremitus, whispered pectoriloquy, egophony) while dulling the sound upon percussion. A common cause of pulmonary consolidation is pneumonia, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given the acute onset of dyspnea, chest pain, cough, and fever. Other causes include pulmonary edema, aspiration of fluids, pulmonary hemorrhage, and lung cancer.

Key learning point: Parenchymal consolidation, as seen in pneumonia, causes dullness to percussion and increased tactile fremitus due to enhanced sound transmission through fluid-filled lung tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Transudation of fluid into the alveoli and the pulmonary interstitium causes pulmonary edema due to left ventricular failure. The backup of fluid seen in left ventricular failure leads to increased hydrostatic pressure in pulmonary capillaries and, consequently, cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Severe pulmonary edema can also manifest with dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and whispered pectoriloquy, all of which are seen here. These signs, however, would manifest bilaterally rather than focally and unilaterally. Furthermore, findings of pulmonary edema would typically include bilateral basilar crackles or rales on respiratory examination.
questions.hint: Dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, bronchial breath sounds, and whispered pectoriloquy are alterations in sound conduction caused by a loss of aeration in lung tissue.

questions.text: A previously healthy 66-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of fever, cough, and right-sided chest pain. Her temperature is 38.8°C and respirations are 24/min. On examination, there is dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and egophony in the right lower lung field. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluid in the pleural space (e.g., due to empyema, pleural effusion) can also cause dullness to percussion, but tactile fremitus would be decreased over the affected area, unlike what is seen in this patient. Dullness to percussion results from the fact that fluid collection outside of the lung parenchyma decreases sound transmission.

B) CORRECT:

Dullness to percussion can indicate pleural effusion, atelectasis, or lung consolidation, but the findings of increased tactile fremitus and egophony make a consolidation most likely. Increased tactile fremitus and egophony occur because a consolidation conducts sound better than air. While pneumonia is the most common cause of a localized consolidation, consolidation can also be due to any infiltrative process (e.g., tumor, pulmonary edema).

Key learning point: Consolidation of a lung segment causes dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and egophony due to enhanced sound transmission through solidified lung tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluid in the interstitial space (e.g., due to pulmonary edema) typically manifests with crackles on pulmonary examination. In the early stages of pulmonary edema, crackles may only be present during late inspiration. Severe pulmonary edema can also manifest with dullness to percussion, increased tactile fremitus, and egophony, but these signs would be expected bilaterally rather than focally and unilaterally, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The collapse of a lung segment (e.g., due to pneumonia or atelectasis) can also cause localized dullness to percussion, as seen here. However, lung collapse is typically characterized by decreased tactile fremitus, unlike what is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Findings expected with air in the pleural space (e.g., due to pneumothorax, tension pneumothorax) include hyper-resonance to percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, decreased breath sounds, and absent egophony. This patient's examination findings are not consistent with pneumothorax.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and localized examination findings suggest community-acquired pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of shortness of breath. She has a history of atopic dermatitis. She does not smoke or use drugs recreationally. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8° F) and respirations are 28/min. She appears anxious and is unable to speak in full sentences. X-rays of the chest are shown. Examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



Chest auscultation
Chest percussion
Chest expansion
Tactile fremitus



A
Decreased breath sounds
dull
asymmetric
decreased


B
Decreased breath sounds
hyperresonant
asymmetric
decreased


C
Fine inspiratory crackles
dull
symmetric
increased


D
Bronchial breath sounds
dull
asymmetric
increased


E
Decreased breath sounds
hyperresonant
symmetric
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atelectasis or a large pleural effusion causes decreased breath sounds, dullness on percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, and unilaterally decreased chest expansion. This patient's chest x-rays do not show features of a pleural effusion (e.g., costodiaphragmatic angle blunting, opacification of a lung field, tracheal shift to the opposite side) or atelectasis (e.g., lobar or lung collapse, tracheal shift to the same side)
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a malignant pleural effusion in a patient with lung cancer

Complete opacification of the left hemithorax (green overlay) is accompanied by mediastinal shift to the contralateral right side (indicated by blue and red lines and arrows). This shift confirms that a space-occupying process, rather than volume loss, is the primary cause of the opacification.

The absence of air in the distal left main bronchus reflects bronchial obstruction and correlates with the patient's clinical history of bronchogenic carcinoma.

T: trachea; Green outline: trachea and main bronchi

B) INCORRECT:

A large pneumothorax causes decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance on percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, and unilaterally decreased chest expansion. A pneumothorax can occur spontaneously (typically affecting young men) and manifests with acute dyspnea and increased radiolucency in the affected lung fields. However, an x-ray would also show a collapsed lung adjacent to the radiolucent region, a tracheal shift to the opposite side, and prominent outlining of the mediastinal, bronchial, and carotid arterial borders, none of which is seen here.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient without a history of trauma

A large left pneumothorax (blue overlay) is seen, with an absence of lung markings peripheral to the collapsed lung (yellow overlay). Contralateral shift of the mediastinum (indicated by arrows) has resulted in a prominent right heart border (white line), and there is slight widening of the left lateral costophrenic angle (angle marker). These findings are consistent with tension pneumothorax. Incidentally noted is a mild rotatory curvature of the upper thoracic spine.

The absence of thoracic trauma suggests a spontaneous pneumothorax.

Dashed white line: visceral pleural line; green overlay: spinous process; red overlay: vertebral pedicles

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with pulmonary fibrosis or pulmonary edema can have fine inspiratory crackles on auscultation, dullness on percussion, symmetric chest excursion, and normal or increased tactile fremitus. Pulmonary edema can occur acutely but pulmonary fibrosis has a more chronic and progressive course. Moreover, a chest x-ray of patients with either pulmonary fibrosis or pulmonary edema would disclose pulmonary infiltrates and decreased lung volume rather than evidence of hyperinflation.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view)

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (hatched green overlay) and the perihilar air space opacities (green overlay) have a bat wing, or butterfly, configuration. Linear interstitial opacities representing Kerley A lines (orange dashed lines) radiate from the hila to the apices and Kerley B lines (white dashed lines) are seen in the lateral mid zones. The costophrenic angles are blunted (arrows) from bilateral pleural effusions.

These features are characteristically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

D) INCORRECT:

These clinical examination findings are consistent with a consolidative process, the most common of which is lobar pneumonia. Pneumonia can also manifest with dyspnea, but this patient lacks other findings of pneumonia, such as a productive cough and fever. Furthermore, her chest x-rays do not have evidence of consolidation.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A large area of opacification (green overlay) in the left lung obscures pulmonary vessels, the left heart border, and the left hilum. Air bronchograms are visible (indicated by red lines), consistent with the presence of air space disease. Non-visualization of the hilum limits the ability to assess for a central mass.

E) CORRECT:

Physical examination findings of hyperresonance, decreased but symmetric chest expansion, and decreased tactile fremitus are consistent with air trapping due to asthma. While physical examination in asthma patients often reveals wheezing, absent or decreased breath sounds (silent chest) raise concern for a severe asthma attack. Similar findings can also be seen in patients with severe emphysema.

See “Overview of pulmonary examination findings” table.
questions.hint: The chest x-rays show increased radiolucency, flattened diaphragm, and wide intercostal spaces, all of which are signs of pulmonary hyperinflation due to air trapping. In a young patient who does not smoke and has a history of atopy, these findings are most likely the result of a severe asthma attack.
